episodes.description: Developed through direct work with leaders of top companies and a research study of 10,000 high potential employees, this session talks about the seven characteristics of a leader that people would willingly follow.
episodes.title: Leadership
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.000 --> 00:00:04.450
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:04.450 --> 00:00:08.402
>> Hi and welcome to BizPro.TV,
I'm your host Vicki Hall and

3
00:00:08.402 --> 00:00:11.257
I'm here with my good friend John Spence.

4
00:00:11.257 --> 00:00:13.985
Today, we're gonna talk
a lot about leadership and

5
00:00:13.985 --> 00:00:18.350
leadership is one of those topics that
is so important to any organization.

6
00:00:18.350 --> 00:00:21.264
But oftentimes,
we make it way too complex.

7
00:00:21.264 --> 00:00:26.231
John has taught leadership for over 20
years with thousands of individuals and

8
00:00:26.231 --> 00:00:31.214
he likes to keep things pretty simple for
us, so it's easy for us to understand.

9
00:00:31.214 --> 00:00:34.891
So today, we're gonna break it down,
make leadership simple.

10
00:00:34.891 --> 00:00:37.847
And I guess I just wanna start out,
John, by saying,

11
00:00:37.847 --> 00:00:41.791
in your experience over the last 20
years with all of the companies and

12
00:00:41.791 --> 00:00:46.196
all of the leadership leaders that you've
worked with, what are some of the key

13
00:00:46.196 --> 00:00:50.829
take-aways that we can help to keep things
simple when we think about leadership?

14
00:00:50.829 --> 00:00:52.459
>> Sure, Vicki.
Thank you.

15
00:00:52.459 --> 00:00:56.814
Well, actually what I did is rather than
try to give you a theory that I created by

16
00:00:56.814 --> 00:01:01.689
myself, I did a survey several years ago
to 10,000 high potential employees at top

17
00:01:01.689 --> 00:01:03.320
companies around the world.

18
00:01:03.320 --> 00:01:06.916
These were the best of the best, the folks
that anyone would love to have in

19
00:01:06.916 --> 00:01:10.222
their company and I asked them a very
focused question which was what

20
00:01:10.222 --> 00:01:13.433
are the characteristics of a leader
you would willingly follow?

21
00:01:13.433 --> 00:01:15.783
Not famous leaders or iconic leaders, but

22
00:01:15.783 --> 00:01:18.784
who is the kind of a person
that you wanna come to work for

23
00:01:18.784 --> 00:01:22.712
everyday that you want as your leader and
they told me seven key things.

24
00:01:22.712 --> 00:01:27.072
They all happen to begin with C and
I'll got ahead and give you the first one,

25
00:01:27.072 --> 00:01:28.860
cuz it's the most important.

26
00:01:28.860 --> 00:01:33.312
The other ones you can sort of mix up,
but the first one is character and

27
00:01:33.312 --> 00:01:36.500
another word here would be integrity or
honesty.

28
00:01:37.510 --> 00:01:40.866
Great research study by Kouzes and
Posner, I know you've studied them, too.

29
00:01:40.866 --> 00:01:44.550
They did a 30 year research study,
4 continents, 3 million respondents and

30
00:01:44.550 --> 00:01:45.642
ask the same question.

31
00:01:45.642 --> 00:01:49.161
That's where I got the question is what
are the characteristics of a leader you

32
00:01:49.161 --> 00:01:50.342
would willingly follow?

33
00:01:50.342 --> 00:01:53.992
Four major answers and
the first one was honesty.

34
00:01:53.992 --> 00:01:57.740
89% of the people worldwide,
that's 3 decades, 4 continents,

35
00:01:57.740 --> 00:02:00.737
3 million respondents all
said that telling the truth,

36
00:02:00.737 --> 00:02:04.620
being honest is the single most important
thing they look for in a leader.

37
00:02:04.620 --> 00:02:06.676
The next one was forward-looking.

38
00:02:06.676 --> 00:02:10.412
Another word for that would be
visionary and a key idea here is,

39
00:02:10.412 --> 00:02:14.801
it's not just the CEO or the senior
management team that sets the vision.

40
00:02:14.801 --> 00:02:18.546
If one person follows you, just one,
you set the vision for the two of you.

41
00:02:18.546 --> 00:02:22.889
So, every leader at every level has
to be forward-looking or visionary.

42
00:02:22.889 --> 00:02:24.298
The next one was competent.

43
00:02:24.298 --> 00:02:28.340
You gotta be extremely good at what you
do and there's two areas of competence.

44
00:02:28.340 --> 00:02:31.909
You gotta be good at your job, highly
competent that I like to use the word,

45
00:02:31.909 --> 00:02:35.322
towering confidence and you have to
be good at your leadership skills.

46
00:02:35.322 --> 00:02:38.761
And then the last of the major four was
inspiring and that doesn't mean that

47
00:02:38.761 --> 00:02:41.775
you've got to go rah, rah,
sis boom, bah and be a cheerleader.

48
00:02:41.775 --> 00:02:43.831
What it means is that
if you're not inspired,

49
00:02:43.831 --> 00:02:45.845
don't expect anyone else
on your team to be.

50
00:02:45.845 --> 00:02:49.280
You've got to be passionate,
committed, excited,

51
00:02:49.280 --> 00:02:51.529
inspired in order to be inspiring.

52
00:02:51.529 --> 00:02:56.310
So, those four all fit up under
that first C of character.

53
00:02:56.310 --> 00:02:58.599
>> Yeah, and character is so important and

54
00:02:58.599 --> 00:03:02.787
what you said about being willing to
follow a leader, I think that is key.

55
00:03:02.787 --> 00:03:06.734
Other things to consider in leadership
that keep it simple for us?

56
00:03:06.734 --> 00:03:09.191
>> Yeah, well,
we'll go through the other C's.

57
00:03:09.191 --> 00:03:12.460
So, the character's first and
it's first among all of them.

58
00:03:12.460 --> 00:03:17.260
The next one that I like is courage and
what they told me here is I

59
00:03:17.260 --> 00:03:22.800
expect my leader to be courageous, to take
big, bold risks, to take tough decisions,

60
00:03:22.800 --> 00:03:27.400
but what I really want is a leader who
is courageous enough to be vulnerable.

61
00:03:27.400 --> 00:03:31.140
To admit, they don't have all
the answers to ask for help.

62
00:03:31.140 --> 00:03:35.447
Unbelievably important thing in being an
effective leader is having the courage and

63
00:03:35.447 --> 00:03:37.095
vulnerability to ask for help.

64
00:03:37.095 --> 00:03:39.956
Now this doesn't mean you should be
sitting in the corner like, yeah,

65
00:03:39.956 --> 00:03:40.963
I don't know what to do.

66
00:03:40.963 --> 00:03:45.934
90% of the time you're courageous,
you're bold, you're a risk taker, but 10%

67
00:03:45.934 --> 00:03:50.508
of the time when you feel overwhelmed you
admit it, when you don't have the answer

68
00:03:50.508 --> 00:03:55.045
you admit it and you show people that
you're courageous enough to be authentic.

69
00:03:55.045 --> 00:03:59.879
>> Courage, I've seen courage in action
and I've seen the opposite of courage in

70
00:03:59.879 --> 00:04:04.441
action and I can clearly see how that is
a huge trait to being a great leader.

71
00:04:04.441 --> 00:04:07.142
What's the next C that we can think about?

72
00:04:07.142 --> 00:04:10.966
>> This C is one that we mentioned
earlier from Kouzes and Posner, but

73
00:04:10.966 --> 00:04:15.628
it's one that's essential in building
trust and respect which is confidence.

74
00:04:15.628 --> 00:04:19.837
And the idea here is that you've got to be
really, really, really good at your job

75
00:04:19.837 --> 00:04:23.758
and really good at your leadership
skills and here's what I share with you.

76
00:04:23.758 --> 00:04:25.559
There's no excuses not to be.

77
00:04:25.559 --> 00:04:29.639
If you're going to be a leader, you've got
to set the example of a being life long

78
00:04:29.639 --> 00:04:33.539
learner and never in the history of
humankind has there been more information

79
00:04:33.539 --> 00:04:35.352
available for free than right now.

80
00:04:35.352 --> 00:04:40.566
So there's no excuses, you should be
watching TED Talks and Big Think and

81
00:04:40.566 --> 00:04:45.108
YouTube videos and listening to
iTunes Podcasts and reading and

82
00:04:45.108 --> 00:04:50.089
reading different magazine and
all those ways to invest in yourself.

83
00:04:50.089 --> 00:04:53.876
Because the more information you have
access to, the more you can help other

84
00:04:53.876 --> 00:04:57.500
people, the more respected you will
be as a leader for your competence.

85
00:04:57.500 --> 00:05:00.922
And if you wanna have a great team and
a great company, having people that

86
00:05:00.922 --> 00:05:04.738
are highly competent, focused and always
getting better every day, what I call

87
00:05:04.738 --> 00:05:08.014
personal [INAUDIBLE] is fundamental
to building your great company.

88
00:05:08.014 --> 00:05:12.477
And if the leader isn't highly competent
in setting that example no one else will

89
00:05:12.477 --> 00:05:13.142
follow it.

90
00:05:13.142 --> 00:05:17.498
>> Yeah, and going back to being a leader
that you wanna follow, I can completely

91
00:05:17.498 --> 00:05:22.590
understand how competence is one of
those things that if you don't have it.

92
00:05:22.590 --> 00:05:25.260
I mean, people are definitely not
going to respect you as a leader and

93
00:05:25.260 --> 00:05:28.030
that's probably a huge component as well.

94
00:05:28.030 --> 00:05:30.020
What's another one,
John that we can think of?

95
00:05:30.020 --> 00:05:32.324
>> The next C is communication.

96
00:05:32.324 --> 00:05:34.671
And again,
when you hear all these, remember,

97
00:05:34.671 --> 00:05:36.628
this isn't a theory that I came up with.

98
00:05:36.628 --> 00:05:40.694
Although I've been studying leadership,
read hundreds of books on it,

99
00:05:40.694 --> 00:05:42.274
lead a couple of companies.

100
00:05:42.274 --> 00:05:46.320
This is what those 10,000 high
potential employees told me and

101
00:05:46.320 --> 00:05:49.390
what they said around
communication was of course,

102
00:05:49.390 --> 00:05:53.155
I expect my leader to be able to
stand up and explain the vision and

103
00:05:53.155 --> 00:05:56.321
give a motivating talk and
give clear expectations.

104
00:05:56.321 --> 00:05:57.346
But what I really,

105
00:05:57.346 --> 00:06:02.340
really want from my leader is someone who
asks great questions and listens intently.

106
00:06:02.340 --> 00:06:04.080
Someone's who curious.

107
00:06:04.080 --> 00:06:07.179
I've hired good people,
they're on my team, I'm leading this team.

108
00:06:07.179 --> 00:06:10.311
Why in the world wouldn't I be
excited about asking them questions,

109
00:06:10.311 --> 00:06:13.443
trying to get their opinion,
they're feedback, they're input.

110
00:06:13.443 --> 00:06:17.306
So you want a leader that's very curious,
constantly asking questions.

111
00:06:17.306 --> 00:06:20.537
And then when someone gives them
the answer, they're an intense listener.

112
00:06:20.537 --> 00:06:21.965
They're using great body language.

113
00:06:21.965 --> 00:06:22.593
They're focused.

114
00:06:22.593 --> 00:06:23.768
They're taking notes.

115
00:06:23.768 --> 00:06:24.494
They're listening.

116
00:06:24.494 --> 00:06:25.613
They're trying to understand.

117
00:06:25.613 --> 00:06:29.188
They're asking more questions and
the other key thing is once they've asked

118
00:06:29.188 --> 00:06:32.928
the question, and listened, and written
notes that they actually apply some of

119
00:06:32.928 --> 00:06:35.640
the things that they've been
told by their team members.

120
00:06:35.640 --> 00:06:40.073
So lots of open, honest,
robust, high trust, high candor,

121
00:06:40.073 --> 00:06:42.175
communication is critical.

122
00:06:42.175 --> 00:06:43.283
Asking great questions and

123
00:06:43.283 --> 00:06:45.793
listening is what they told me
they wanted from their leader.

124
00:06:45.793 --> 00:06:49.350
>> Yeah, I can see how these are kind
of building upon each other.

125
00:06:49.350 --> 00:06:53.600
Because if a leader doesn't have character
and their communicating with you, maybe in

126
00:06:53.600 --> 00:06:57.320
a way that they think is effective,
you're gonna see right through that.

127
00:06:57.320 --> 00:07:00.860
So I can see how these are just
building one on top of the other, but

128
00:07:00.860 --> 00:07:02.560
I think there's more, John.

129
00:07:02.560 --> 00:07:05.311
>> Yep, the next one is collaboration.

130
00:07:05.311 --> 00:07:09.364
And again, here's what the folks told
me is I understand you're my leader.

131
00:07:09.364 --> 00:07:11.595
I know you're my boss, I got that.

132
00:07:11.595 --> 00:07:15.413
You've got more seniority, rank and
title, but don't lord that over me.

133
00:07:15.413 --> 00:07:19.650
If every now and then you gotta say, do
this, because I'm you're boss, I'm fine.

134
00:07:19.650 --> 00:07:25.158
But the rest of the time, I wanna see you
as a team player as a partner and a peer.

135
00:07:25.158 --> 00:07:27.269
I wanna see my leader
roll up their sleeves.

136
00:07:27.269 --> 00:07:29.229
Get in there shoulder to shoulder with us.

137
00:07:29.229 --> 00:07:30.399
Work as part of the team.

138
00:07:30.399 --> 00:07:34.520
Do the work and communicate, and
work with us as a peer as a partner.

139
00:07:34.520 --> 00:07:38.228
And then if you say,
do it, because I told you.

140
00:07:38.228 --> 00:07:39.459
Do it, because I'm your manager.

141
00:07:39.459 --> 00:07:40.996
Do it, because I own the company.

142
00:07:40.996 --> 00:07:42.363
I'll handle that.

143
00:07:42.363 --> 00:07:45.120
The reverse is if you constantly
lead from that command and

144
00:07:45.120 --> 00:07:49.059
control thing that ain't gonna work and
your best people will leave immediately,

145
00:07:49.059 --> 00:07:52.343
because they get frustrated and
they don't want to be lead that way.

146
00:07:52.343 --> 00:07:54.666
>> Yeah, we talk about teamwork so often.

147
00:07:54.666 --> 00:07:59.669
And oftentimes, we miss the whole
leadership part of teamwork.

148
00:07:59.669 --> 00:08:04.641
And from what you're saying, collaboration
as a leader really can play into whether

149
00:08:04.641 --> 00:08:06.447
or not the team is successful.

150
00:08:06.447 --> 00:08:10.638
>> Absolutely and then part of it too is
that we've got a different make up of

151
00:08:10.638 --> 00:08:12.921
the people in the workforce right now.

152
00:08:12.921 --> 00:08:14.361
As the millennials come in and

153
00:08:14.361 --> 00:08:17.931
they're gonna be the largest section
of workers over the next ten years,

154
00:08:17.931 --> 00:08:22.170
the baby boomers and gen X are moving out,
retiring, going to other places.

155
00:08:22.170 --> 00:08:26.790
You're gonna look for a leader that is
if they're not a team member, if they

156
00:08:26.790 --> 00:08:30.880
don't work well with folks, if they don't
treat other people with respect and

157
00:08:30.880 --> 00:08:32.650
respect their information, their ideas,

158
00:08:32.650 --> 00:08:37.290
their experience, their suggestions,
you can't actually build a cohesive team.

159
00:08:37.290 --> 00:08:42.376
Another big idea with the millennials
is the next C, which is compassion.

160
00:08:42.376 --> 00:08:43.571
I'm 52 years old.

161
00:08:43.571 --> 00:08:45.392
When I grew up, when my boss said, jump.

162
00:08:45.392 --> 00:08:47.100
I said, how high, sir?

163
00:08:47.100 --> 00:08:49.086
It was all command and control, all men.

164
00:08:49.086 --> 00:08:53.414
Now it's changed and employees today,
want more flexibility.

165
00:08:53.414 --> 00:08:56.806
They want more of say in their outcome,
they want you to be compassionate and

166
00:08:56.806 --> 00:08:57.659
understand that.

167
00:08:57.659 --> 00:09:00.422
Yes, this is my job, but I have other
things that are just as important to me.

168
00:09:00.422 --> 00:09:03.012
My family, my hobbies, my faith.

169
00:09:03.012 --> 00:09:05.386
I play on a sports team,
whatever it might be.

170
00:09:05.386 --> 00:09:08.220
I'll give you my 40,
maybe my 50 hours a week.

171
00:09:08.220 --> 00:09:11.843
But after that, I'm out of here and I'm
going home to spend time with my friends,

172
00:09:11.843 --> 00:09:13.996
my family to go surfing,
whatever it might be and

173
00:09:13.996 --> 00:09:16.322
it's not that they don't
have a strong work ethic.

174
00:09:16.322 --> 00:09:20.087
It's they have a different
value system that says,

175
00:09:20.087 --> 00:09:22.833
I need to be felt like I'm important.

176
00:09:22.833 --> 00:09:24.137
I do important work.

177
00:09:24.137 --> 00:09:25.619
I'm making a difference in the world.

178
00:09:25.619 --> 00:09:28.879
I'm contributing to the company,
title isn't that important.

179
00:09:28.879 --> 00:09:32.250
They want fair pay, but
it isn't all about money.

180
00:09:32.250 --> 00:09:35.380
So, they need a leader who's
compassionate enough to understand

181
00:09:35.380 --> 00:09:38.260
that this job isn't their whole life.

182
00:09:38.260 --> 00:09:40.697
That their really focused on
other parts of their life and

183
00:09:40.697 --> 00:09:42.981
they want to feel good while
they're in the company,

184
00:09:42.981 --> 00:09:45.907
that the leader truly cares about them and
has compassion for them.

185
00:09:45.907 --> 00:09:49.609
>> And it makes a huge difference is you
work for somebody who cares about you.

186
00:09:49.609 --> 00:09:53.857
It definitely makes a big difference
in the leadership style of that leader.

187
00:09:53.857 --> 00:09:56.503
Is there a final C that you
wanna share with us today, John?

188
00:09:56.503 --> 00:10:00.189
>> Yeah, and Vicky, I'll touch on
what you just said is, it's very,

189
00:10:00.189 --> 00:10:03.752
very hard to be inspired, passionate,
committed and excited for

190
00:10:03.752 --> 00:10:06.571
a leader that isn't and
doesn't treat you fairly.

191
00:10:06.571 --> 00:10:12.087
Interesting piece of research shows that
the number one factor in highly engaged,

192
00:10:12.087 --> 00:10:17.234
satisfied and loyal customers is engaged,
satisfied and loyal employees.

193
00:10:17.234 --> 00:10:20.860
Another phrase I love to use here is the
customer's experience will never exceed

194
00:10:20.860 --> 00:10:22.257
the employee's experience.

195
00:10:22.257 --> 00:10:24.579
So if the employee doesn't
have a leader they admire,

196
00:10:24.579 --> 00:10:26.098
there isn't good communication.

197
00:10:26.098 --> 00:10:29.919
They're not treated with compassion,
you're not gonna see them do that for

198
00:10:29.919 --> 00:10:33.289
your customers which typically
runs to a thing called bankruptcy.

199
00:10:33.289 --> 00:10:37.850
Now if you've done the other six things
as well and you've become a good leader,

200
00:10:37.850 --> 00:10:39.268
you've got a good team.

201
00:10:39.268 --> 00:10:41.830
You're building a successful
company you're growing.

202
00:10:41.830 --> 00:10:46.221
The seventh C is contribution and
this is where the leader says,

203
00:10:46.221 --> 00:10:51.038
I'm gonna leave a legacy that I'm
gonna make long-term decisions.

204
00:10:51.038 --> 00:10:55.574
In America, at least,
we run on a very tight schedule of meeting

205
00:10:55.574 --> 00:10:59.109
quarterly goals or
meeting Wall Street demands.

206
00:10:59.109 --> 00:11:03.821
And oftentimes, our leaders, unfortunately
make very short-term decisions, but

207
00:11:03.821 --> 00:11:07.369
the best leaders and I see leaders
in other countries like Japan,

208
00:11:07.369 --> 00:11:12.624
where they make 10, 15, 20-year horizons
to allow them to make 20-year decisions.

209
00:11:12.624 --> 00:11:13.972
So as contribution goes,

210
00:11:13.972 --> 00:11:18.720
it's what I call planting the seeds of
trees under which you may never sit.

211
00:11:18.720 --> 00:11:19.836
Giving back to your community.

212
00:11:19.836 --> 00:11:21.384
Building a legacy of leadership.

213
00:11:21.384 --> 00:11:25.363
Creating other leaders and taking
the resources, and the authority, and

214
00:11:25.363 --> 00:11:29.470
the respect that you've earned by doing
the first six exceedingly well, and

215
00:11:29.470 --> 00:11:31.250
becoming a great leader.

216
00:11:31.250 --> 00:11:35.996
And then giving back as a servant leader
and leaving the organization better than

217
00:11:35.996 --> 00:11:39.853
you found it and better not just for
a few years, but for decades.

218
00:11:39.853 --> 00:11:44.299
>> Yeah, so John these seven Cs that you
just mentioned are very thorough, but

219
00:11:44.299 --> 00:11:47.644
keep things simple when we
wanna talk about leadership.

220
00:11:47.644 --> 00:11:50.282
Are there any final thoughts
that you had on leadership

221
00:11:50.282 --> 00:11:52.064
before we wrap up today's session?

222
00:11:52.064 --> 00:11:55.378
>> Yeah, I think the most important
thing to remember here is to be a great

223
00:11:55.378 --> 00:11:58.421
leader of others, you must first
be a great leader of yourself.

224
00:11:58.421 --> 00:12:02.193
So my recommendation is to think about
the seven that I've shared with you and

225
00:12:02.193 --> 00:12:05.908
then look at other things that you've had,
other influences you've had,

226
00:12:05.908 --> 00:12:07.434
leaders you've worked with.

227
00:12:07.434 --> 00:12:08.780
Good leaders, bad leaders.

228
00:12:08.780 --> 00:12:12.383
What you've learned from them,
your own personal value system and

229
00:12:12.383 --> 00:12:16.301
work on creating what I call your own
personal philosophy of leadership or

230
00:12:16.301 --> 00:12:20.283
your own personal leadership competency
model where you've got a written

231
00:12:20.283 --> 00:12:24.322
list of the key things that you wanna do
to be the kind of leader you wanna be and

232
00:12:24.322 --> 00:12:28.019
leave the kind of leadership legacy
you've always wanted to leave.

233
00:12:28.019 --> 00:12:31.811
And when you've got that, you can use it
as a touchstone for every day when you go

234
00:12:31.811 --> 00:12:35.321
in the office, every day you go to work,
to how you wanna act and behave and

235
00:12:35.321 --> 00:12:38.964
impact the other people in your
organization as a highly effective leader.

236
00:12:38.964 --> 00:12:41.899
>> So John, thank you for
that recap of the seven Cs of leadership.

237
00:12:41.899 --> 00:12:47.449
As always, you kept things simple on
a topic that can often be way too complex.

238
00:12:47.449 --> 00:12:50.336
So for BizPro.TV, I'm Vicky Hall.

239
00:12:50.336 --> 00:12:51.946
>> I'm John Spence.

240
00:12:51.946 --> 00:12:54.607
>> Thank you for
spending your time with us.

241
00:12:54.607 --> 00:13:03.483
[MUSIC]

episodes.description: A clear explanation of specifically how to help a work group or team become a high-performance team. Covers the role of the team, the purpose of the team and the six key elements of a high-performance team.
episodes.title: High Performance Teams
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.000 --> 00:00:04.550
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:04.550 --> 00:00:06.930
Hi, and welcome to Bizpro.TV.

3
00:00:06.930 --> 00:00:10.920
I'm your host, Vicki Hall, and
I'm here today with John Spence.

4
00:00:10.920 --> 00:00:15.010
John, today we're gonna talk about high
performance teams, and as we all know,

5
00:00:15.010 --> 00:00:17.690
high performance teams
are hard to come by.

6
00:00:17.690 --> 00:00:20.193
And most things we do, we work in a team.

7
00:00:20.193 --> 00:00:23.128
And there's a big difference
between being in a work group and

8
00:00:23.128 --> 00:00:25.250
being in a high-performance team.

9
00:00:25.250 --> 00:00:28.996
So today, John is gonna talk to us
about what it means to be on and

10
00:00:28.996 --> 00:00:31.130
work in a high-performance team.

11
00:00:31.130 --> 00:00:32.340
John?
>> Yeah.

12
00:00:32.340 --> 00:00:34.038
This is a topic I've been studying for
years.

13
00:00:34.038 --> 00:00:36.292
I'm actually in the middle of
writing a new book all around

14
00:00:36.292 --> 00:00:38.350
high-performance teams.

15
00:00:38.350 --> 00:00:42.760
And I've created a model, working with
hundreds of teams around the world

16
00:00:42.760 --> 00:00:46.630
at top companies, all the way up to
a group of the United States Navy Seals.

17
00:00:46.630 --> 00:00:49.130
And what I've looked for is the pattern.

18
00:00:49.130 --> 00:00:52.228
What is the pattern of what
truly great teams have?

19
00:00:52.228 --> 00:00:59.320
And I'm gonna describe it using
a couple of letters, and it's dmc CMD.

20
00:00:59.320 --> 00:01:00.210
That's the model.

21
00:01:00.210 --> 00:01:01.776
So let's start with the first d.

22
00:01:01.776 --> 00:01:03.802
The first d is direction, but

23
00:01:03.802 --> 00:01:08.310
the key idea behind direction
is it's a shared direction.

24
00:01:08.310 --> 00:01:11.080
Someone else might tell the team
what they need to accomplish.

25
00:01:11.080 --> 00:01:14.320
They might give them an end goal and
say we're at a now and

26
00:01:14.320 --> 00:01:16.240
I wanna be at z by the end of the year.

27
00:01:16.240 --> 00:01:19.920
But then, a high performance team has the
ability to put their thumb print on it,

28
00:01:19.920 --> 00:01:21.610
to take some ownership.

29
00:01:21.610 --> 00:01:23.550
The phrase I always use
when describing this is,

30
00:01:23.550 --> 00:01:26.770
if you don't have a say in the outcome,
you won't have a stake in the outcome.

31
00:01:26.770 --> 00:01:30.280
So step one, in a high performance
team is getting the team together,

32
00:01:30.280 --> 00:01:31.410
discussing this, and

33
00:01:31.410 --> 00:01:35.708
finding a way to customize the way they're
gonna approach achieving their outcome.

34
00:01:35.708 --> 00:01:39.318
And give them a clear shared direction
that they're all committed to and

35
00:01:39.318 --> 00:01:40.212
aligned around.

36
00:01:40.212 --> 00:01:42.034
>> I can understand how that would be so

37
00:01:42.034 --> 00:01:45.437
important because if the team was
not going in the same direction,

38
00:01:45.437 --> 00:01:48.313
then obviously it wouldn't
be a high performing team.

39
00:01:48.313 --> 00:01:50.000
So that one's pretty clear.

40
00:01:50.000 --> 00:01:53.200
What's another tip that we
can take away in creating and

41
00:01:53.200 --> 00:01:55.540
working in a high performance team.

42
00:01:55.540 --> 00:02:00.763
>> The next level is,
this whole model's built on the two M's.

43
00:02:00.763 --> 00:02:04.938
And the first M is measurement and
in order to stay aligned and be moving in

44
00:02:04.938 --> 00:02:10.050
the same direction, you have to have
clear metrics of what success looks like.

45
00:02:10.050 --> 00:02:14.570
And the word I use here to describe it,
which is very important is, binary.

46
00:02:14.570 --> 00:02:19.000
The measurements must be one, zero,
black, white, yes, no, no guessing.

47
00:02:19.000 --> 00:02:23.990
One of my very favorite business phrases
is, ambiguity breeds mediocrity.

48
00:02:23.990 --> 00:02:27.470
So, a high performance team
takes the time to sit down and

49
00:02:27.470 --> 00:02:32.620
clearly write out their goals,
the metrics, how things will be measured.

50
00:02:32.620 --> 00:02:35.530
In an unambiguous way, so
there's no guessing whatsoever.

51
00:02:37.470 --> 00:02:41.940
>> I can see how often times in teams
we don't measure our results and

52
00:02:41.940 --> 00:02:46.280
the way you've defined it is
that binary process makes it so

53
00:02:46.280 --> 00:02:48.640
clear and so easy for us to understand.

54
00:02:48.640 --> 00:02:51.230
What's another way to look
at a high performance team?

55
00:02:51.230 --> 00:02:55.520
>> And you're gonna see in a minute Vicky,
why that idea of binary is so critical.

56
00:02:55.520 --> 00:02:59.790
But before we get there, the two C's and
I'll put these two together.

57
00:02:59.790 --> 00:03:02.111
The first C is competence.

58
00:03:02.111 --> 00:03:04.540
You wanna get the best people you
can possibly get on your team.

59
00:03:04.540 --> 00:03:05.510
It just makes sense.

60
00:03:05.510 --> 00:03:07.665
If you wanna have a great
high performance team,

61
00:03:07.665 --> 00:03:10.041
you have to have great high
performing individuals.

62
00:03:10.041 --> 00:03:14.390
And another reason that is, is A players
only wanna play with other A players.

63
00:03:14.390 --> 00:03:17.110
If I'm going to be on a team,
a high performance team,

64
00:03:17.110 --> 00:03:21.240
I expect that everyone else on
the team with me is highly competent.

65
00:03:21.240 --> 00:03:22.820
The next C is communications.

66
00:03:22.820 --> 00:03:26.410
And the keywords around
communications are open, honest,

67
00:03:26.410 --> 00:03:30.750
robust, and the keyword is transparent,
and here's why.

68
00:03:30.750 --> 00:03:33.940
People without access to information
do not have to take accountability

69
00:03:33.940 --> 00:03:35.070
for their actions.

70
00:03:35.070 --> 00:03:38.300
If you go to someone on the team and you
say, how you doing on the Spence project

71
00:03:38.300 --> 00:03:40.910
and they go,
I got no idea what you're talking about.

72
00:03:40.910 --> 00:03:42.050
No one told me about Spence.

73
00:03:42.050 --> 00:03:43.590
I didn't know we work with them.

74
00:03:43.590 --> 00:03:46.560
If that's true you cannot
hold them accountable.

75
00:03:46.560 --> 00:03:50.520
However, if you say, no no no no no, I
sent you an email, we talked about this in

76
00:03:50.520 --> 00:03:53.710
the weekly meeting, I left you
a voicemail, I carved it in your

77
00:03:53.710 --> 00:03:57.150
desk with a knife, I sent a pigeon to
your house with a note on its leg.

78
00:03:57.150 --> 00:04:01.722
You have all the information that I have,
then you can hold that person accountable.

79
00:04:01.722 --> 00:04:04.716
It used to be that people thought
information was power, and

80
00:04:04.716 --> 00:04:08.825
that's not true, sharing information
with others, allows you to empower them,

81
00:04:08.825 --> 00:04:10.720
which increases your power.

82
00:04:10.720 --> 00:04:11.980
So, in a high performance team,

83
00:04:11.980 --> 00:04:15.290
you want the very best players you
can get that are highly competent.

84
00:04:15.290 --> 00:04:18.860
Then you want lots and
lots of frank, courageous, open, and

85
00:04:18.860 --> 00:04:20.230
transparent communication.

86
00:04:21.430 --> 00:04:22.490
>> So critical.

87
00:04:22.490 --> 00:04:25.916
And you know some of the things that
you just touched on actually remind

88
00:04:25.916 --> 00:04:28.489
of a recent conversation
we had around leadership.

89
00:04:28.489 --> 00:04:33.426
So it sounds like these characteristics
of a high performing teams are oftentimes

90
00:04:33.426 --> 00:04:36.900
built upon the same kinds of
principles as leadership.

91
00:04:36.900 --> 00:04:40.810
So certainly there may be
a little overlap there.

92
00:04:40.810 --> 00:04:43.770
>> Yeah there's a lot of similarities

93
00:04:43.770 --> 00:04:47.410
in what it takes to be an effective
leader of any team or any organization.

94
00:04:47.410 --> 00:04:49.980
And communications is
definitely one of those.

95
00:04:49.980 --> 00:04:54.650
Another big one, which is the next one in
the model, and this says we have d for

96
00:04:54.650 --> 00:04:56.320
direction shared.

97
00:04:56.320 --> 00:05:00.480
M for measurements binary,
highly competent people with open, honest,

98
00:05:00.480 --> 00:05:02.070
transparent communication.

99
00:05:02.070 --> 00:05:04.030
And now here's where
the whole model changes.

100
00:05:04.030 --> 00:05:05.820
This is really where
the power of the model.

101
00:05:05.820 --> 00:05:08.500
The next M is mutual accountability.

102
00:05:08.500 --> 00:05:12.470
And this is where everybody on the team
takes both personal accountability for

103
00:05:12.470 --> 00:05:16.690
delivering what they say they'll deliver,
for getting their stuff in on time,

104
00:05:16.690 --> 00:05:19.680
world class work every time,
you can trust me.

105
00:05:19.680 --> 00:05:21.190
I am reliable, I am dependable.

106
00:05:21.190 --> 00:05:23.357
I have full accountability for
doing a great job at my job.

107
00:05:23.357 --> 00:05:26.462
And they also have mutual
accountability in the team,

108
00:05:26.462 --> 00:05:29.768
which is where everybody holds
each other accountable for

109
00:05:29.768 --> 00:05:33.340
delivering great work that
exactly meets the measurements.

110
00:05:33.340 --> 00:05:36.050
Which is why the measurements are so
important.

111
00:05:36.050 --> 00:05:40.313
If you don't have clear binary, specific
measurements, here's what it sounds like.

112
00:05:40.313 --> 00:05:42.807
Hey, Dave I don't think
you're doing a good job.

113
00:05:42.807 --> 00:05:46.570
Or Sue doesn't seem to me like
you achieved that on time.

114
00:05:46.570 --> 00:05:51.000
When the measurements are binary, there's
no think, feel, see, there's no opinion.

115
00:05:51.000 --> 00:05:52.500
You either did it or you didn't.

116
00:05:52.500 --> 00:05:54.290
You got it done on time or you didn't.

117
00:05:54.290 --> 00:05:55.530
The work was correct or not.

118
00:05:55.530 --> 00:05:56.980
You met your numbers or not.

119
00:05:56.980 --> 00:05:58.770
No guessing, no ambiguity.

120
00:05:58.770 --> 00:06:03.830
What this does is it removed personality,
politics, emotion from the situation.

121
00:06:03.830 --> 00:06:07.871
If I'm gonna hold somebody else on my team
accountable I don't want it to seem like

122
00:06:07.871 --> 00:06:09.350
it's me versus you.

123
00:06:09.350 --> 00:06:13.290
It's me and you together versus
the measurement that we agreed on.

124
00:06:13.290 --> 00:06:16.030
That way I can be, what I call,
rigorous without being ruthless.

125
00:06:16.030 --> 00:06:20.600
I can push my team members to be really
good, but I'm never attacking them.

126
00:06:20.600 --> 00:06:22.678
Which leads to the third
level of accountability.

127
00:06:22.678 --> 00:06:25.079
And I haven't figure out a good name for
this but I call it,

128
00:06:25.079 --> 00:06:26.800
reciprocal accountability.

129
00:06:26.800 --> 00:06:30.840
Which is where if you're a great team
player you not only hold other people

130
00:06:30.840 --> 00:06:35.370
accountable, but you expect and even
encourage them to hold you accountable.

131
00:06:35.370 --> 00:06:38.730
So if you slip and you're not performing
and someone else on the team calls you on

132
00:06:38.730 --> 00:06:41.490
it, you don't get mad, you don't
get defensive, you don't get angry.

133
00:06:41.490 --> 00:06:43.060
You say thank you.

134
00:06:43.060 --> 00:06:43.930
I appreciate that.

135
00:06:43.930 --> 00:06:48.440
You're exactly right, the binary goal,
I'm not meeting it, I apologize,

136
00:06:48.440 --> 00:06:49.800
I'll get on it right away.

137
00:06:49.800 --> 00:06:54.382
And that's really what differentiates
a high performance team from other teams,

138
00:06:54.382 --> 00:06:56.287
is that level of accountability.

139
00:06:56.287 --> 00:07:01.180
>> You know, as you were going through the
mutual accountability part of this model.

140
00:07:01.180 --> 00:07:03.885
One of the things I can
think of that we hear so

141
00:07:03.885 --> 00:07:06.533
often times is people say it's not my job.

142
00:07:06.533 --> 00:07:10.514
And when we hear that it sounds
like maybe that would be

143
00:07:10.514 --> 00:07:15.590
a trigger to identify a less
performing team, is that correct?

144
00:07:15.590 --> 00:07:16.380
>> Yeah.

145
00:07:16.380 --> 00:07:18.870
Well this is again and
you hit it perfectly Vicki.

146
00:07:18.870 --> 00:07:22.405
When you take the time to communicate,
in our model, very clear

147
00:07:22.405 --> 00:07:26.673
specific measurable goals and the person
accepts accountability for that.

148
00:07:26.673 --> 00:07:30.243
And they do not deliver, then it's clear
to the rest of the team that they've been

149
00:07:30.243 --> 00:07:34.041
given the resources, the authority, the
time, the budget, everything they need.

150
00:07:34.041 --> 00:07:37.437
Their goals are clear,
there is no guessing, no ambiguity, and

151
00:07:37.437 --> 00:07:39.416
they've accepted responsibility,

152
00:07:39.416 --> 00:07:43.329
then it's easy to deal with that
decisively because there is no guessing.

153
00:07:43.329 --> 00:07:46.792
Which brings me to the last D,
the final D in the model which is perfect

154
00:07:46.792 --> 00:07:49.510
id the discipline to
actually do this every day.

155
00:07:49.510 --> 00:07:53.870
To build this level of accountability,
honesty, candor,

156
00:07:53.870 --> 00:07:56.590
sheer direction into something
that drives the team every day.

157
00:07:56.590 --> 00:07:59.656
It's on every agenda,
you discuss it in every meeting, and

158
00:07:59.656 --> 00:08:03.219
you constantly make sure that you're
going back to those first five.

159
00:08:03.219 --> 00:08:07.436
And ensuring that the team has the clear
direction, specific binary measurement

160
00:08:07.436 --> 00:08:11.990
goals, top people, great communication,
and high levels of accountability.

161
00:08:11.990 --> 00:08:13.000
And you never let it slip.

162
00:08:13.000 --> 00:08:16.500
What happens in a work group or
a regular team is every now and

163
00:08:16.500 --> 00:08:18.620
then when there's an emergency,
they pull together.

164
00:08:18.620 --> 00:08:19.791
And they can be an amazing team.

165
00:08:19.791 --> 00:08:22.420
They're fire fighting, they're in
there together doing all that stuff.

166
00:08:22.420 --> 00:08:25.458
And then, as soon as it's over,
they slip back into being a workgroup and

167
00:08:25.458 --> 00:08:26.660
not performing.

168
00:08:26.660 --> 00:08:31.150
With a high performance team, 90% of the
time they're performing exceedingly well.

169
00:08:31.150 --> 00:08:34.545
And that 10%, when they slip, they pull
each other back, they hold each other

170
00:08:34.545 --> 00:08:38.000
accountable, and they rise back up
to being a high performance team.

171
00:08:38.000 --> 00:08:41.877
>> Well John, sign me up because that
sounds like a team that I would wanna work

172
00:08:41.877 --> 00:08:42.878
on and in for sure.

173
00:08:42.878 --> 00:08:46.958
Is there any other tips or tricks or
any information that you wanna share about

174
00:08:46.958 --> 00:08:50.350
high performing teams to
kinda wrap us up for today?

175
00:08:50.350 --> 00:08:50.854
>> Yeah.

176
00:08:50.854 --> 00:08:52.592
[LAUGH] This is not easy.

177
00:08:52.592 --> 00:08:57.520
Only about 10% of teams ever achieve
the high performance teams level.

178
00:08:57.520 --> 00:08:59.289
Part of it is you need to
look at it too and say,

179
00:08:59.289 --> 00:09:01.680
do we truly need to build that
kind of a team for this project?

180
00:09:01.680 --> 00:09:05.710
Because sometimes you don't need a team,
sometimes a work group is just fine.

181
00:09:05.710 --> 00:09:07.748
Sometimes a regular
inter-departmental team or

182
00:09:07.748 --> 00:09:09.640
cross-functional team would be great.

183
00:09:09.640 --> 00:09:12.384
But if it's something mission
critical that's gotta get done and

184
00:09:12.384 --> 00:09:13.757
it's gotta get done perfectly.

185
00:09:13.757 --> 00:09:17.989
You need a high performance team and you
need to understand it takes a lot of work,

186
00:09:17.989 --> 00:09:20.180
a lot of discipline, great people.

187
00:09:20.180 --> 00:09:23.623
It is not easy and
only a few teams get to that level.

188
00:09:23.623 --> 00:09:27.848
>> Sounds like it's deliberate to be
on a high performance team for sure.

189
00:09:27.848 --> 00:09:29.658
So that's all for today.

190
00:09:29.658 --> 00:09:32.610
This is BizPro.TV, thank you.

191
00:09:32.610 --> 00:09:33.585
I'm Vicki Hall.

192
00:09:33.585 --> 00:09:35.427
>> And I'm John Spence.

193
00:09:35.427 --> 00:09:37.800
>> Have a good day.

194
00:09:37.800 --> 00:09:46.284

1
00:00:04.640 --> 00:00:06.750
Hi and welcome to BIZPRO.TV.

2
00:00:06.750 --> 00:00:09.140
I'm your host Vickie Hall and

3
00:00:09.140 --> 00:00:13.250
our segment today is going to
be about business excellence.

4
00:00:13.250 --> 00:00:17.030
And we all know that there was a really

5
00:00:17.030 --> 00:00:21.540
clear line between businesses that
excel and businesses that don't.

6
00:00:21.540 --> 00:00:25.720
And to talk about that today I want
to introduce John Spence, John.

7
00:00:25.720 --> 00:00:26.632
>> Good to be here with you.

8
00:00:26.632 --> 00:00:27.371
>> Welcome.
>> Well Vicki,

9
00:00:27.371 --> 00:00:31.230

00:11:58.560 --> 00:12:02.990
So that step 1 is make it super easy
to understand green, yellow, red.

240
00:12:02.990 --> 00:12:05.710
Step two then is make it highly visible.

241
00:12:05.710 --> 00:12:09.780
Cut down all the trees, no place to hide,
put it up on a white board,

242
00:12:09.780 --> 00:12:14.315
on a dashboard, on a computer, so
that everybody knows where everybody

243
00:12:14.315 --> 00:12:17.535
from the top of the organization to
the bottom, stands on their goals.

244
00:12:17.535 --> 00:12:19.765
So, very easy to understand.

245
00:12:19.765 --> 00:12:22.785
And highly, highly visible so
everybody sees it.

246
00:12:22.785 --> 00:12:25.065
Now, here's what happens
in most organizations,

247
00:12:25.065 --> 00:12:29.655
about 10% of the people love that
because they're your top performers.

248
00:12:29.655 --> 00:12:31.890
They know they're gonna be green,
green, green.

249
00:12:31.890 --> 00:12:36.540
Love it, it makes them proud, they can't
wait till they put up the tracking.

250
00:12:36.540 --> 00:12:40.050
About 70 to 80% of the people in the
middle of the organization freaked out,

251
00:12:40.050 --> 00:12:41.310
they looked like a deer in the headlights.

252
00:12:41.310 --> 00:12:44.698
[SOUND] And then about 10 or 15%,
hopefully it's less at the bottom,

253
00:12:44.698 --> 00:12:48.251
fall down on the ground like a two year
old with a wet diaper and start crying and

254
00:12:48.251 --> 00:12:50.074
going it's not fair, it's not fair.

255
00:12:50.074 --> 00:12:53.390
And for those people what we like to
call is make them available to industry

256
00:12:53.390 --> 00:12:55.637
because they've just told you,
I'm mediocre,

257
00:12:55.637 --> 00:12:59.440
I'm gonna be yellow red yellow red
yellow red and not get out of there.

258
00:12:59.440 --> 00:13:02.970
So now what do you do about that big group
in the middle that's all freaked out?

259
00:13:02.970 --> 00:13:05.020
Here's what you do, it's the fourth step.

260
00:13:05.020 --> 00:13:07.110
Coach, mentor, train, support.

261
00:13:07.110 --> 00:13:10.900
Most people think that when I'm tracking
you, I'm tracking you to punish you.

262
00:13:10.900 --> 00:13:13.730
To you know show that you're missing your
goal, that I'm not gonna give you your

263
00:13:13.730 --> 00:13:17.210
promotion, I'm not gonna give you
a bonus or give you a raise, and

264
00:13:17.210 --> 00:13:20.100
they see it as tracking as punitive.

265
00:13:20.100 --> 00:13:22.060
What you do here is you flip it around and
say no, no, no.

266
00:13:22.060 --> 00:13:25.070
When you slip from green to yellow
we're not gonna get mad at you or

267
00:13:25.070 --> 00:13:27.160
yell at you we're gonna
rush in to help you.

268
00:13:27.160 --> 00:13:31.100
We're gonna give you coaching, training,
mentoring, support, and everybody on

269
00:13:31.100 --> 00:13:34.440
the team's gonna gather around you
to get from yellow back into green.

270
00:13:34.440 --> 00:13:37.530
At first people don't really believe it.

271
00:13:37.530 --> 00:13:38.260
They struggle with it.

272
00:13:38.260 --> 00:13:42.210
But after a little while they realize,
every time I slip and every time I go into

273
00:13:42.210 --> 00:13:46.530
yellow, everybody comes and
helps me and gets me back up in green.

274
00:13:46.530 --> 00:13:48.960
And when that happens
they want more tracking.

275
00:13:48.960 --> 00:13:52.200
The other side of this is
when someone doesn't do that.

276
00:13:52.200 --> 00:13:56.160
At least everyone around the organization
knows that everyone was trying to get them

277
00:13:56.160 --> 00:13:58.660
from yellow into green and
they slipped from yellow into red.

278
00:13:58.660 --> 00:14:02.910
Which brings me to the fifth and final
one which is celebrate success lavishly.

279
00:14:02.910 --> 00:14:06.340
If someone does a great job, and they
deliver their results, and everything's

280
00:14:06.340 --> 00:14:10.320
done well and they stay in green,
everybody should cheer and celebrate that.

281
00:14:10.320 --> 00:14:14.080
But when someone doesn't do it and you
can't get them from yellow into green or

282
00:14:14.080 --> 00:14:18.890
red into yellow then it's time to
deal decisively with mediocrity and

283
00:14:18.890 --> 00:14:20.710
help them leave the organisation.

284
00:14:20.710 --> 00:14:22.550
But again if you've been coaching,
mentoring, training and

285
00:14:22.550 --> 00:14:26.190
supporting, when they leave and I've got
a great Jack Welsh quote here that I like,

286
00:14:26.190 --> 00:14:29.190
I never fired anybody with surprise.

287
00:14:29.190 --> 00:14:31.740
And this also means that no
one else was surprised and

288
00:14:31.740 --> 00:14:34.570
they think that you treat them fairly and
reasonably.

289
00:14:34.570 --> 00:14:38.210
That they were asked to held accountable,
they accepted the accountability and

290
00:14:38.210 --> 00:14:38.930
didn't deliver.

291
00:14:40.050 --> 00:14:43.390
>> Wow, John that's a lot of information
but really good information.

292
00:14:43.390 --> 00:14:45.049
And I love the equation and

293
00:14:45.049 --> 00:14:49.208
how the first parts of the equation
kind of set you up for success.

294
00:14:49.208 --> 00:14:53.020
And then there's that great multiplier
at the end so that's really fantastic.

295
00:14:53.020 --> 00:14:58.558
Any final thoughts on execution or
just excellence in general for our group?

296
00:14:58.558 --> 00:15:01.120
>> Yeah,
these are four fundamental things.

297
00:15:01.120 --> 00:15:03.490
They're not the only things, you have
to have great financial management,

298
00:15:03.490 --> 00:15:05.320
good quality product and service.

299
00:15:05.320 --> 00:15:08.530
Understanding of your market,
financing, all that sort of stuff.

300
00:15:08.530 --> 00:15:13.490
But to me if you do these four things,
surround yourself, hire, keep,

301
00:15:13.490 --> 00:15:16.070
train the very best talent.

302
00:15:16.070 --> 00:15:19.910
You create a winning culture that
also delivers the business results.

303
00:15:19.910 --> 00:15:21.730
You have extreme customer focus.

304
00:15:21.730 --> 00:15:25.820
Internal customers, your employees, and
external customers who pay all the bills.

305
00:15:25.820 --> 00:15:28.680
And then you take those first three
things and you make sure that you

306
00:15:29.750 --> 00:15:33.530
apply disciplined execution, that you
take all that great information and

307
00:15:33.530 --> 00:15:35.800
actually deliver results
in the marketplace.

308
00:15:35.800 --> 00:15:39.760
I believe if you focus on these four
things, it'll create a good solid bedrock

309
00:15:39.760 --> 00:15:43.000
for the long term and
sustainable success of the organization.

310
00:15:43.000 --> 00:15:44.090
>> That's fantastic stuff.

311
00:15:44.090 --> 00:15:46.520
I know that I've learned quite a bit.

312
00:15:46.520 --> 00:15:49.830
And I hope that you guys did too.

313
00:15:49.830 --> 00:15:52.570
I think for today that's a wrap.

314
00:15:52.570 --> 00:15:55.320
For BizPro.TV, I'm Vicki Hall.

315
00:15:55.320 --> 00:15:56.640
>> I'm John Spence.

316
00:15:56.640 --> 00:16:02.951
>> We'll see you next time.

317
00:16:02.951 --> 00:16:09.759
[MUSIC]

WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.000 --> 00:00:04.625
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:04.625 --> 00:00:07.046
Hi, welcome to BizPro.TV.

3
00:00:07.046 --> 00:00:09.313
I'm your host, Vicki Hall.

4
00:00:09.313 --> 00:00:13.446
Today's session is going to be
focusing on the web of value.

5
00:00:13.446 --> 00:00:16.656
And quite frankly,
when John told me about the session today,

6
00:00:16.656 --> 00:00:19.680
I did not know really where
he was gonna go with it.

7
00:00:19.680 --> 00:00:21.795
So I wanna introduce John Spence and

8
00:00:21.795 --> 00:00:25.613
he's gonna talk us through what
that means the web evaluation.

9
00:00:25.613 --> 00:00:29.376
>> [LAUGH] It's an interesting term,
it's one I developed and

10
00:00:29.376 --> 00:00:33.981
it's based on what I think are three
essential things that any company.

11
00:00:33.981 --> 00:00:38.252
But especially a small to medium size
business really needs to focus on to build

12
00:00:38.252 --> 00:00:39.621
a high level of success.

13
00:00:39.621 --> 00:00:43.164
And I'm great with the acronyms so

14
00:00:43.164 --> 00:00:47.449
this one is V-O-C M-O-T and W-O-M.

15
00:00:47.449 --> 00:00:50.450
VOC, this is one of those things
I jump up and down about.

16
00:00:50.450 --> 00:00:53.470
It's one of my strongest
business beliefs that whoever

17
00:00:53.470 --> 00:00:57.980
owns the voice of the customer VOC,
owns the marketplace.

18
00:00:57.980 --> 00:01:02.150
That whoever understands her customer the
best, who's the closest customer, creates

19
00:01:02.150 --> 00:01:07.110
the best relationship, listens to what's
important to them, what they care about.

20
00:01:07.110 --> 00:01:12.160
Whoever understands the customer
the best has a huge market advantage.

21
00:01:12.160 --> 00:01:16.979
And I've made a recommendation to
several of my clients in the past that

22
00:01:16.979 --> 00:01:19.561
they put a formal system in to do this.

23
00:01:19.561 --> 00:01:23.671
And I'll give you four questions that
we help people ask that really get to

24
00:01:23.671 --> 00:01:27.040
the heart of listening to
the voice of the customer.

25
00:01:27.040 --> 00:01:29.740
And I'll give you a quick example of
how I did this a couple of years ago.

26
00:01:29.740 --> 00:01:33.104
I was working for a company out of Texas,
a due diligence firm that

27
00:01:33.104 --> 00:01:36.727
they would fly in to look and
see about whether the numbers were right.

28
00:01:36.727 --> 00:01:39.687
One company should buy another company,
and I ask them,

29
00:01:39.687 --> 00:01:41.360
do you have a Pareto business?

30
00:01:41.360 --> 00:01:43.297
And they say,
what do you mean by a Pareto business?

31
00:01:43.297 --> 00:01:49.260
And I said, does 80% of your revenue
come from 20% of your customers?

32
00:01:49.260 --> 00:01:53.145
And they said, no, no, no, 90% of our
revenue comes from 10% of our customers.

33
00:01:53.145 --> 00:01:55.146
I said, we'll deal with that later.

34
00:01:55.146 --> 00:01:58.236
I said, let's get together a client panel,
let's get together five or

35
00:01:58.236 --> 00:01:59.800
six of your top customers.

36
00:01:59.800 --> 00:02:03.460
Bring them in and we'll ask them some
questions in front of your whole team,

37
00:02:03.460 --> 00:02:05.380
which is about 170 people.

38
00:02:05.380 --> 00:02:08.951
So we got 6 of their top clients
to represent at about 35,

39
00:02:08.951 --> 00:02:11.790
40% of their total revenue
out of a couple 100 clients.

40
00:02:11.790 --> 00:02:15.320
These six key ones and
I asked them these four questions.

41
00:02:15.320 --> 00:02:20.200
Number one, why specifically do
you do business with this company?

42
00:02:20.200 --> 00:02:22.940
And I'll change the phraseology a bit,
it would be like this.

43
00:02:22.940 --> 00:02:26.246
Why specifically do you do
business with our company?

44
00:02:26.246 --> 00:02:29.480
What are the top three or
four reasons you hired us?

45
00:02:29.480 --> 00:02:32.930
And all six of them explained it and
it was roughly the same thing.

46
00:02:32.930 --> 00:02:34.010
And I turned to the company and said,

47
00:02:34.010 --> 00:02:37.150
you just got your brand,
that's your unique selling proposition.

48
00:02:37.150 --> 00:02:41.280
If all these people spend millions
of dollars with you, for basically

49
00:02:41.280 --> 00:02:45.400
the same four or five reasons, this
probably why other people would hire you.

50
00:02:45.400 --> 00:02:48.050
So why specifically do
you do business with us?

51
00:02:48.050 --> 00:02:50.710
The top three or four reasons,
that's your brand.

52
00:02:50.710 --> 00:02:53.760
Number two,
what do we do now that frustrates you?

53
00:02:53.760 --> 00:02:57.350
What do we do that you wish we'd start,
stop, change, do differently?

54
00:02:57.350 --> 00:02:59.920
What would make it easier
to do business with us?

55
00:02:59.920 --> 00:03:03.353
Again, all six answered
roughly the same thing.

56
00:03:03.353 --> 00:03:06.148
And I turned to the company and
said, great, fix that stuff.

57
00:03:06.148 --> 00:03:10.280
If that's stuff that your customers
don't like, let's change that right now.

58
00:03:10.280 --> 00:03:15.750
Question number three, what would it take
to earn more or all of your business?

59
00:03:15.750 --> 00:03:19.920
What would we have to do to
become your preferred supplier or

60
00:03:19.920 --> 00:03:24.400
your sole source supplier and
deliver everything to you?

61
00:03:24.400 --> 00:03:27.420
Again cuz you see a trend here,

62
00:03:27.420 --> 00:03:32.330
they all roughly said the same thing,
and I turned them and said, great.

63
00:03:32.330 --> 00:03:34.900
Do more of that and
you will get more of their business.

64
00:03:34.900 --> 00:03:39.450
And the last thing I asked was, what
would it take for you to terminate them?

65
00:03:39.450 --> 00:03:41.901
What would we do that
would cause you to be so

66
00:03:41.901 --> 00:03:44.500
unhappy that you would
fire us immediately?

67
00:03:44.500 --> 00:03:48.453
And they just said a few things,
breach of confidentiality,

68
00:03:48.453 --> 00:03:52.150
professional misconduct,
giving us false numbers.

69
00:03:52.150 --> 00:03:53.930
Pretty straightforward stuff and
I looked at the company and

70
00:03:53.930 --> 00:03:56.400
said, don't do those things.

71
00:03:56.400 --> 00:03:59.863
So at the end of that,
of listening to the voice of the customer.

72
00:03:59.863 --> 00:04:03.698
They understood how to brand themselves,
how to go to market, what most people

73
00:04:03.698 --> 00:04:07.600
would buy from them, how to increase or
how to make their customers happy?

74
00:04:07.600 --> 00:04:09.130
How to increase their customer's business,

75
00:04:09.130 --> 00:04:11.710
and how not to lose their
customer's business?

76
00:04:11.710 --> 00:04:14.320
I've recommended this sort
of an idea to dozens and

77
00:04:14.320 --> 00:04:17.950
dozens of companies and
very few ever do it.

78
00:04:17.950 --> 00:04:22.945
Probably 90% of the organizations I
work with are unfortunately pathetic at

79
00:04:22.945 --> 00:04:25.864
truly listening to
the voice of the customer.

80
00:04:25.864 --> 00:04:28.510
>> [LAUGH] And
I can only imagine how important that is.

81
00:04:28.510 --> 00:04:33.269
And unfortunately you're right, I bet many
companies don't really ask their customers

82
00:04:33.269 --> 00:04:35.656
what they think and
listen to that feedback.

83
00:04:35.656 --> 00:04:39.665
And I can actually think of some companies
right now, off the top of my head,

84
00:04:39.665 --> 00:04:42.433
that they probably haven't
asked their customer.

85
00:04:42.433 --> 00:04:44.314
So that's a good point.

86
00:04:44.314 --> 00:04:45.765
>> I'll take the port from there.

87
00:04:45.765 --> 00:04:49.370
But I've talked to CEOs about this,
companies that have hired me.

88
00:04:49.370 --> 00:04:51.460
And they've said,
I don't wanna ask the customer,

89
00:04:51.460 --> 00:04:55.610
because I'd be afraid of what they said or
if they complained, I'd have to fix it.

90
00:04:55.610 --> 00:04:58.150
So I'd rather not hear
the voice of the customer.

91
00:04:58.150 --> 00:04:59.517
>> Path of least resistance, right John?

92
00:04:59.517 --> 00:05:01.361
[LAUGH]
>> Yes, [LAUGH] absolutely.

93
00:05:01.361 --> 00:05:02.423
>> So this web of value,

94
00:05:02.423 --> 00:05:05.850
I'm starting to understand a little
bit about creating this value.

95
00:05:05.850 --> 00:05:10.150
So the first thing is to listen to
the customer, understand what they want or

96
00:05:10.150 --> 00:05:11.800
they need from you.

97
00:05:11.800 --> 00:05:13.050
What else is this web?

98
00:05:14.620 --> 00:05:18.270
>> Well the next one we're gonna
talk about is MOT, moments of truth.

99
00:05:18.270 --> 00:05:22.951
And many of the folks I work with say that
this is one of the most powerful ideas I

100
00:05:22.951 --> 00:05:23.467
teach.

101
00:05:23.467 --> 00:05:27.891
This idea came from years ago, there was
a gentleman named Jan Carlzon that took

102
00:05:27.891 --> 00:05:29.950
over as CEO of Scandinavian Airway.

103
00:05:29.950 --> 00:05:32.247
And the airway was in
very serious trouble,

104
00:05:32.247 --> 00:05:34.710
really on the verge of bankruptcy.

105
00:05:34.710 --> 00:05:35.460
And he looked at it and said,

106
00:05:35.460 --> 00:05:37.720
we're gonna have to rebuild
this thing from the bottom up.

107
00:05:37.720 --> 00:05:39.820
I mean we just gotta change everything.

108
00:05:39.820 --> 00:05:42.570
And he said as long as we're
gonna rebuild this company,

109
00:05:42.570 --> 00:05:45.760
why don't we rebuild it on the backs
of the very best customers?

110
00:05:45.760 --> 00:05:47.330
And in the airline industry,

111
00:05:47.330 --> 00:05:52.350
the very best customers are people like
me, on the road 150, 200 days a year.

112
00:05:52.350 --> 00:05:55.544
I don't get to pick where I go,
I've got to buy plane ticket,

113
00:05:55.544 --> 00:05:59.117
I've got to be there,
I'm on the plane quickly, I'm off quickly.

114
00:05:59.117 --> 00:06:00.660
I fly Delta most of the time.

115
00:06:00.660 --> 00:06:03.156
We have a joke that I probably have
to go through Atlanta when I die.

116
00:06:03.156 --> 00:06:07.190
But what we're looking for here is
what he said, we wanna get the very,

117
00:06:07.190 --> 00:06:09.120
very best customers.

118
00:06:09.120 --> 00:06:13.160
Then he said, let's look at every place
we touch them, all of the touch points.

119
00:06:13.160 --> 00:06:16.150
From when they pickup the phone to call
us, to when they get home with their

120
00:06:16.150 --> 00:06:19.970
luggage, what are all the different
places we interact with the customer?

121
00:06:19.970 --> 00:06:24.840
Then out of those, let's figure out
the three, four, five moments of truth.

122
00:06:24.840 --> 00:06:29.146
The make or break things that we must do
flawlessly, to take that customer and

123
00:06:29.146 --> 00:06:32.143
make sure that they have
an outstanding experience.

124
00:06:32.143 --> 00:06:36.610
And I'm gonna switch gears here now, cuz
I always use restaurants as an example.

125
00:06:36.610 --> 00:06:39.160
I did a little research and
for the average restaurant,

126
00:06:39.160 --> 00:06:41.460
if you were to leave your house,
drive over have dinner, and

127
00:06:41.460 --> 00:06:45.930
drive back to your house,
there's about 170 touch points.

128
00:06:45.930 --> 00:06:49.710
Is it easy to find,
does it have a big sign out front?

129
00:06:49.710 --> 00:06:52.410
Is the ingress and
egress easy to get in and out?

130
00:06:52.410 --> 00:06:54.780
Are the parking spaces wide enough?

131
00:06:54.780 --> 00:06:56.456
Is the parking lot clean?

132
00:06:56.456 --> 00:06:58.057
Is the shrubbery attractive?

133
00:06:58.057 --> 00:06:59.640
Is it the right temperature
when you go in?

134
00:06:59.640 --> 00:07:03.940
Is the music too loud or not loud enough
on and on and those are all touch points.

135
00:07:03.940 --> 00:07:04.790
But basically for

136
00:07:04.790 --> 00:07:09.070
every restaurant on the face of the Earth
there's only four moments of truth.

137
00:07:09.070 --> 00:07:10.940
Four things they've got to do and
I use the word over and

138
00:07:10.940 --> 00:07:14.680
over again flawlessly if you wanna take
someone that came in for dinner and

139
00:07:14.680 --> 00:07:17.050
turn them into a raving fan a patron.

140
00:07:17.050 --> 00:07:18.670
Who comes back over and over again and

141
00:07:18.670 --> 00:07:22.470
tells everybody about how great your
restaurant is, just four things.

142
00:07:22.470 --> 00:07:26.000
And I've asked many, many crowds this,
and they almost always get it.

143
00:07:26.000 --> 00:07:30.710
Here it is, good quality food,
good service, reasonable prices

144
00:07:30.710 --> 00:07:34.290
according to the quality of the food and
